titleStmt.title: Letter from Isabel Kynnersley (née Walker), Loxley, to Walter Bagot, Blithfield, 1609 July 27: manuscript signed
titleStmt.author: Kynnersley, Isabel

availability.licence: This allows you to use our transcriptions without additional permission provided that you cite the Early Modern Manuscripts Online (EMMO) Project at the Folger Shakespeare Library as the source and that you license anything you create using the transcriptions under the same or equivalent license. EMMO and the Folger waive permission fees for non-commercial publication by registered non-profits, including university presses, regardless of the license they use. For information about using the images that correspond to the transcriptions, see Image Permissions (http://www.folger.edu/permissions).

msIdentifier.collection: Papers of the Bagot family of Blithfield, Staffordshire

msContents.summary: When Bagot was last at Loxley she would have pushed the writer down the stairs and broken her neck if he had not been there. Urges that Bagot, Mr. Rudyerd (Richiarde), and her husband make an end of this business. She ought to live as a wife or depart with a portion. Is locked up and allowed to see no one. Writing this letter has been dangerous.

msItem.author: Kynnersley, Isabel
msItem.title: Letter from Isabel Kynnersley (née Walker), Loxley, to Walter Bagot, Blithfield, 1609 July 27: manuscript signed

namespace.tagUsage: Marks the beginning of a page or page spread.
Marks a line break in the manuscript.
Records information such as page numbers that appear on every page.
Includes notes, including administrative notes written on the manuscript.
Marks a logical division of the text. In letters, for example, marks the body, superscription, endorsement, etc.
Marks the page or div header.
Marks labels in the text.
Marks paragraphs in the text.
Contains opening information that appears outside a paragraph, for letter-like documents.
Contains closing information that appears outside a paragraph, for letter-like documents.
Contains additional information that appears after the closer, for letter-like documents.

Used to mark other divisions in the text. For letter-like documents, the dateline, salute, and signed elements in our texts do not always follow the TEI model, and therefore they are marked by seg elements.
Marks additions to the text, authorial and otherwise.
Marks abbreviation markers, including brevigraphs, macrons, superscription, and suspension.
Marks special characters such as the thorn, the archaic letter that looks like a "y" and may be updated to "th".
Marks special characters that may function as abbreviation or insertion markers.
Marks a word (or more, for compound words), giving the original and regularized versions.
Offers the transcription of a word used to generate the diplomatic and semi-diplomatic readings.
Offers the regularized spelling of a word.
Marks a space character in the text.
Marks a punctuation character in the text.
Marks a place where the text is illegible.
Marks a place where EMMO supplies illegible text.
Marks non-English words.
Identifies personal names in the text.
Identifies place names in the text.
Identifies titles in the text.
Identifies measurements and amounts in the text.
Marks sections of the text that are otherwise highlighted.
